>>28104914
A) Wealth gap is wholly and entirely irrelevant, and B) the level of personal debt carried is a good metric for how well people are doing financially. It's a far more useful metric for how well an economic system works for individuals than income inequality, which as I stated is completely irrelevant.

Why is income inequality irrelevant? Because our economies are not zero-sum. Every productive activity generates new value, which adds to the whole of our economy. The fact that a small portion of the country makes far more in a month than I do in a year has no impact on my life as long as I can make enough money to live comfortably and pay my bills.

The US is not even remotely pure socialist. Norway is basically the same as we are only with slightly more welfare. We have massive regulatory bodies and enormous tomes of statute that control markets and businesses and constrain our economic output. We have substantial tax burdens, especially on businesses compared to other nations, and we've basically priced ourselves out of industries like manufacturing.

>>28105018
>but not anymore
We still do, really. As I mentioned, public utilities are essentially owned by states or municipalities, we have industries such as defense which are basically entities of the federal government, we have huge public universities that offer services beyond education such as research and medical services, and banks are essentially controlled by the Federal Reserve.

There will always, always, always, without fail, (yes, always, in every scenario, no exceptions) be a small number of people who hold outsized power in any given political or economic system. That is a universal constant and it is not controvertible by any means we have available to us. It has always been true, throughout human history, and it will always be true for the foreseeable future. It's true in socialist systems, it's true in capitalist systems, it's true in feudalist systems, and it'll even be true in a communist system if anyone ever manages to implement one. That's because most people need some kind of leadership, and when none is present, someone will inevitably step into that place, even if they don't want it. People will choose them and simply follow them in whatever they do.

More to the point, this doesn't matter to me. Power being amassed by some guy I've never met or heard of only starts to matter to me if it begins to affect my everyday life. Under a properly formed capitalist system, with certain protections in place against monopolies and such, one person or a small group of people could never amass enough power to do anything that would significantly reduce my quality of life. Therefore, I do not care.

1/2

I've never done it myself, but if I were to try I'd say there's two plays, long and short. The long game that could take weeks to play out
>meet eyes, nod hello with a smirk one day
>get her name, say hi as you pass each other
> have small talk for a few moments at the gym when you see each other
>chat to each other between sets
>invite her to grab some lunch after gym, or better, meet up later that day to hang
out
>grab her number
All on different days so you don't come on too strong

The short game is to nod hello and if she responds positively to go right up to her, chat her up, and ask her out lightheartedly before there's a chance for any tension or awkwardness to build up. If it's a no, accept the rejection completely casually, unphased, and go back to whatever you're doing. It's not awkward if there's no prior relationship on the line.

>>28101894
Confronting supervisors is rarely a good idea, since you are unlikely to win. From the information you shared, you seem to know what you are doing, but policies and management is hindering your work-style. From my experience, you should do exactly what you are told to do, and follow the process that is established by your company. Basically, treat yourself as a wagie, which will be frustrating, but it will help you avoid conflicts. However, the most important thing you should do is document every job/project you complete per instructions. Include a summary of the task, the time it took, and issues you encountered. You should also document any exchange you had with your supervisor and stakeholders regarding these tasks. The goal of documenting this information is for you to have hard facts and data when the confrontation eventually comes up. For me, I was successfully able to shift a task and responsibility that I was told to do, to the correct department by using company policy.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

I took a big dose of shrooms once and started thinking alone these lines. I started ruminating on all the stuff I had ever done wrong, all the chances I'd ever blown, all the people I didn't treat the way I should whether intentional or unintentional. After a while I began to think that there is no way that I could have acted any differently or I wouldn't be me. Being the person I am, being in those situations at those specific times, the only decision that I could have made were the ones that I did make. The type of person I became was primed to act the way that I did (break up with her, take this major, accept this job) from before I was born. The circumstances I was born into formed my early development and core memories, which affected how I acted as a child, which affected how I acted as a youth, and on and on.
The shrooms made me think of it like water flowing down the side of a mountain: if you think about it abstractly or generically, you might think that the water could take an almost infinite number of paths. But in reality millions or billions of years of geology, forest development, weather, etc. already predetermined a single path that the water will take from any given starting point. It will always find its level, and can only follow one possible route. Maybe if the water started running 6 inches to the left it would take another path, but whichever way it starts the path is set by forces that shaped it long before the water hit the mountainside. Everything I ever regretted was inevitable and everything I will regret is inevitably going to happen, because when it comes time to act then I can only act as I've been prepared to act, in circumstances or settings that depend on everything that I've done before.

One of my worst drug experiences of all time. Fucked me up to this day. I've never taken psychedelics since.

You are just getting red-pilled, people need games in their life, look at sports and puzzles. For centuries, people needed games to regain enchantment in their lives. You can learn a lot about someone by playing Risk with them. Video games are a novelty, but so is gambling and darts to an extent. Yet unlike most art forms or athletics, video games are tethered to a web of capitalism, just look at the minor technological leap from the PS4 to PS5. Do I regret playing Street Fighter 2 for hours as a kid? No, those were good memories. But those were memories, I still love Street Fighter, but I refuse to buy any games that require micro-transactions. Video games are a distraction from reality, but if you never let nostalgia or Nintendo own you, you're free. Play Donkey Kong until that screen says "game over" then stop. Keep the games around for guests or family moments, but don't invest money into them. It's a time killer and nothing less.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I felt that way for a while in the last year but most of it came from the realization that I could be doing something else instead. Playing video games is okay, in fact I like it a lot more than I did in the past year, but I also don't burn myself on one type of game or series like I was before. I also have other things going on now. If that is how you want to relax, then you should go for it.
Also video games are great to play with other people. Not just watching along, but actually playing multiplayer games. Some of the best multiplayer games unfortunately in this day and age are online multiplayer games that don't even support LAN, but you can still play a ton of games that were released that have good couch co-op or general multiplayer.
Of course I am also not going to sit here and tell you that you should continue despite being burnt out- it is perfectly normal after 20 years or so to get burned out of a hobby and there are a bunch of other things that you can be doing. In that aforementioned year, I found this site that helped me:
https://www.videogamealternatives.com/2018/05/Master-list-of-the-best-video-game-alternatives.html
When you are a gamer your entire life, you can't fathom the idea that there are other things to do other than playing games- but there's an entire world out there. Last thing to keep in mind: you enjoyed the time you spent, so you didn't waste any of it. If you are 30, you still have plenty of time to learn something new. People that say that the brain stops developing after 24 don't realize that this is development, not function. The human brain is supposed to learn and make new connections, that's function and not development.

I imagine it's harder than otherwise, but still doable. You just need to be more deliberate about it. The most important thing is practice, but you should first supplement it with some theory. Read books on empathy, human relationships, experiences of other aspies, etc. Then get out and socialize.

Same as anybody else: hobby groups, team sports, volunteering, friends, dance classes, online dating. All of these work if you have the right attitude.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28102906
I grew up as the weird outcast nerd kid, girls laughed at me, relationships/sex was something that happens in stories or to other people. It never occurred to be to try to date, I just sat in my room and waited for something to happen just like in my japanese animes (spoiler: it never did). Around 25 I had enough, so I started researching how human romantic and sexual relationships work (/adv/ was one of my big sources back in the day), and figuring out how do I get one. It took about five years before I started getting dates consistently. It's neither quick nor easy, but definitely possible if you keep trying and (critically important) learn from failure.
Main points:
- Understand yourself. What's your personality like, what are your flaws and strong points? What precisely are the reasons you don't have a girlfriend? What kind of a girl you find attractive and what do you want from a relationship?
- Consider your hypothetical future gf. What does she want from a partner - can you offer her those things? If not, that's something to work on. Where does she spend her time? That's how you know where to meet her.
- Go out and socialize. You will never find a gf shut inside your room. Find some activities that allow you to meet new people regularly. Ideally something you'll enjoy for its own sake, otherwise you'll be annoyed and grumpy and just drive people away.
- Don't be afraid of failure. If you have no social skills, you will make many embarrassing missteps. Think of them as learning opportunities. The good thing about social skills is they can be practiced.
- Do not be unattractive. A defeatist bitter whiny needy self-deprecating attitude (seen in this very thread) is the most unattractive thing ever, far more important than your height or muscles. Book 'Models' explains this really well, you can find it on libgen.

What's the point of a best friend? That's the same point of a girlfriend. A girlfriend isn't a generic thing, it's a person you really click with, someone who gets you and you get them. It's a person you can share experiences with, and go through hard times together.

It's a person you can rely on to always have your back, and with whom you can be safe being vulnerable with. Which girl you choose, and how you behave/treat her matters. The point of dating, that is the initial part where you're going on dates, is to evaluate whether you have a connection with the other person that you can build upon.

A girlfriend isn't entertainment. A girlfriend is a close buddy. They're not always on. They're not always exciting indeed more often than not it's just going to be mundane routine. They're not always happy and you won't always like them.

Sometimes my wife and I can go a month without liking each other. But we still love each, and experience has taught us that eventually we'll get over it, we'll find a way to talk about it and work through it to resolve the problem. Relationships aren't fairytales.

No one outside of you can ever fill all those empty spaces inside of you. No amount of external approval, friends, sex or any other stuff is going to make you fill you up. Some of it is going to make you feel even more empty, and more alone than ever before. You have to deal with your demons inside of you. You need your own approval, your own love, before you can love someone else and be loved in return.

Seek therapy to work through your stuff anon, that's the best place for you right now.

posts.com: Your brain is wired to avoid unpleasant feelings because it helped you survived in the wild. In the modern age however it undermines you by denying you self-growth because it is painful to do so. Include the prevalence of instant gratification in the form of refined food, addictive social apps and so on and it's all too easy to distract yourself in a way that pleasantly sates your worries. This leads people to think they don't want to fix their problems, but in truth the world undermines self-growth and rewards distractions. It also fucks with your baseline dopamine, as constantly hitting those dopamine highs on a regular basis means seeking it out as the new baseline, making things like studying seem WAY harder than it should. People want to fix their problems, they just don't understand what's trapping them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28103894
Mostly true if you're asking for advice.

The thing about advice is that most of it isn't surprising. It's the same shit you already knew you potentially needed to do. Most problems have, like, 2-4 "sensible" solutions, tops, and coming up with those solutions demands almost zero creativity. So basically anyone asking for advice doesn't actually have a "help me brainstorm solutions" problem, they either have a motivation problem or are seeking arguments explaining the superiority of courses of action they've already considered. They don't want it yet, and they're hoping you make them want it. Saying this calls out this dynamic.

Put another way, by definition, most people having a problem are "dealing with it" by following that problem's "path of least resistance". A way of doing things ends up being the path of least resistance usually because it's in some way easier, more tempting, more fun, or at a glance looks like it'll get better outcomes than other harder solutions, even if it doesn't reduce or eliminate the problem.

If someone wants to get off the path of least resistance, usually, they can - but they have to want to do so. This means its likely that people on the path of least resistance at some level feel want to be there, or at least don't care enough to take action to change course. Thus, they largely don't want to fix their problems.

>>28103270
Ok, first of all, people that tend to think things too much have this nasty habit of analising situations/reactions to try and predict outcomes, for example
>X has a dog
>X loves that dog
>X's dog dies
>since X loves that dog and people don't like it when they lose something they love, then X is sad
>i SHOULD act sad or comfort X
This is using analisis, notice that not once during that thought process you felt what X was feeling (in fact, maybe you didn't feel anything at all), you understood it based on deduction and past data.
Most people (specially men), develop this way of thinking if they never were good at dealing or understanding emotions. But the problem is that if you never train this skill (empathy) you'll eventually get stuck, because (same as logical thinking) this is a specialiced skill, if you try to cover the gap with other skills, you may be able to get away with it while doing simpler stuff, but you will get a 40% efficiency at best.
Basically, it's like forcing your CPU to do its job while also doing all of the GPU's work too.
If you do it too much, you'll get stuck in your own head, and even your perception of things can get warped.
For social skills (and specially for talking with women) you need both, empathy to be able to conect with the other person and "read the mood", and logical thinking to not act like a retard.

I hope my explanation was clear enough, since i'm sleepy as shit.

posts.com: How are you supposed to know if you're in love with someone vs just having a crush/liking them a lot while you're dating?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Infatuation is all those initial feelings you have when you first meet someone, like them, start dating and go through the honeymoon phase.

Love comes much later, a year or more into the relationship when you really know each other, your traits, your quirks, your weaknesses, all the things. Love feels the same way you feel about your immediate family, only with romantic love you want to create your own family with that person.

It's a complicated matter.

ALL WOMEN (literally all, 100%) have an instinct of "upgrading", and WILL be tempted to cuck their partner with a perceivedly "better" one whenever the opportunity arises.

I firmly believe there are women whose "threshold of infidelity" so to speak is so hard to reach that, as long as she is with a significantly attractive partner who checks all the boxes, there isn't a man on Earth who is "Chad enough" to make her stray, even if her partner himself isn't a "Chad". But if the same woman finds herself with a sonewhat loser partner, and the partner has no problem with her going on "girls night outs" at nightclubs, and she meets a super handsome and sweet Chad there, she IS gonna cheat. Because the difference between Chad and her partner is just too large, and the opportunity (and being slightly tipsy, and being on her fertile period, and having her girl friends incentivizing her to fuck Chad, etc, will cross her infidelity threshold).

In conclusion, not all women will cheat, simply because some of them are morally sound enough to resist mild temptations even when the opportunity is good, and won't ever be exposed to a strong enough temptation. Also, the more valuable you are as a man, the less her threshold will be put to test.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I hate falling in love.
I've been talking to a girl who just so happens to live on the other side of the globe and I thought, this time, surely I wont fall into the love trap again. SURELY the distance is so great my brain and heart wont even consider it.
But then she had go and take a long break from the net, and so I realized how attached I'd actually gotten to her, and it's only gotten worse.
I know most of it is me projecting my ideals on her, since it's online and obviously we don't see our "full selves", but we've talked for almost a year now and I know her relatively well. And you know, I can't really stop my heart from feeling the things it does even if I outright tell myself it's unrealistic.
I know I'm never going to see her, I know we'll never meet and I know we can never ever be in a relationship.
And that's why I hate catching feelings for someone. Especially online. I had been doing so well since my last relationship ended. I though I'd managed to finally be happy on my own. I loved myself and my time on my own. But now it's like, this girl has redefined my context.
I want to be with her, I want to do anything and everything with her, and I'm just experience such intense feelings when I'm talking with her.
I wish she didn't have to live on the opposite side of the planet, and I wish we had met some years earlier, then maybe things could have worked.
And it's that "what if" that is the most depressing. I know you shouldn't think about things that way, because it's just a bunch of stuff that is out of your control. But it just hurts, that someone you actually click with can exist somewhere else entirely and there's not much you can do about that.
Thanks for [spoiler]not[/spoiler] reading my rant or whatever

>>28101825
it's precisely what OCD does. the thinking, ruminating, and reasoning for obsessing is patterned exactly the same even if there's no physical component. even if it's not a clinical description ppl sometimes refer to it as it 'pure-o', purely obsessive OCD. i had your exact problem, same ppl call it HOCD (homosexually themed OCD). the compulsion so to speak is to 'test' and think and reflect and do research on the topic. you wouldn't think that's all that pernicious but when you involve the kind of endless worry spiral OCD patients have the tendency to fall into it becomes pathological. and before you ask full recovery is documented, as well as possible, even if some say it's not. case in point is that i personally can these days ask the question of whether i'm gay without worrying. and i'm satisfied with answering it on my own terms (self-observing isn't the same as actively introspecting, mind you. a lot of things about yourself you just decide, much to the chagrin of ppl holding certain ideas about the nature of sexuality and identity. as obvious as it is, a good example of this is that being called a fag on here doesn't necessarily entail fucking men, nor really need it for the accusing poster mentally involve considering the other person's sexuality factually and in depth. it's just said.)
you should look into it, i think you would find the resources on it all very helpful. just make sure not to make it an obsession (which is VERY easy to do when you're already scared as you've probably noticed) and your anxiety and uncertainty about the matter will abate with time. therapy is helpful for most, as well. the key is generally to just stop thinking about it, as paradoxical as that seems. physics is happy to conclude the existence of a particle with a 5-sigma certainty and even then you could always do more experiments. ignoring the fact OCD has you investigate yourself under false pretenses and ridiculous notions about self you can be going forever

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28103666
But why are you allowing their actions affect you? Do you not have control still over what affects you and what doesn't?

I think you're missing a key step in your causal reasoning. Yours is like this: they do something, then you feel badly as a result of their action. But that's not quite true. What is really happening looks like this instead: they do something, you judge it to be something you should react badly to, then you feel badly as a result of your opinion and judgments.

You're missing that key middle step where you are the one responsible for your emotional reactions to events; and thus then by lashing out at random women online you are, in truth, lashing out at the hidden, culpable self that you project onto them.

>>28104222
Yeah just keep the resolution at the native resolution (should be the highest one, 1920x1080), then assuming you are running windows you want to search in the Start Menu for the Setting "Make Everything Bigger", which should be under Settings > Display > Make everything bigger, and choose a higher number than 100% such as 150% to scale up the text so that it is not small anymore. If you try that and it still looks grainy, search up "Adjust Cleartype text" and go through the calibration of how text is rendered on the screen (usually you can just accept the default and it will look good anyway).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28104282
Ok I think I actually misunderstood the question. If you are asking whether it is possible to keep the resolution at 1366x768 on the 1080p display, the answer is no. The reason is that it is upscaling to fit the size of the screen. It does this by multiplying the number of pixels. It is like looking at a 480p image on a 1080p screen, it will always look worse quality than watching a 1080p image on a 1080p screen. You can set the scaling so that it is centered in the middle of the screen instead of scaled, but this will result in a smaller image (but maintain the sharpness). If you want it to fill the screen, it must stretch pixels.

>>28104326
and yes I was wondering why it looks better on my old laptop and worse on this one as its newer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28104338
It looks better on the old laptop because you were using the "native resolution". The screen on the old laptop is made up of 1366 pixels horizontally and 768 pixels vertically. Therefore, when the resolution is set at 1366x768, the number of pixels perfectly matches the resolution. The new laptop has a higher native resolution at 1920x1080, so when you set the resolution to 1366x768, there is not a perfect match between the pixels and the resolution, resulting in blurriness or graininess, because it must stretch the resolution to cover all of the pixels. To get around this, most people will set the resolution to match the number of pixels (the native resolution), then if the text is too small, use the Make everything bigger setting to increase the size of everything so that it is not too small. Doing it this way will keep the sharpness, but also not make everything look tiny.

>>28104375
The best setting should be 1920x1080 resolution set to 150% size. It won't look exactly like the other one because you would need closer to 140% zoom (1080 / 768). If you want perfect sharpness, you should set to 1920x1080 resolution at 100% zoom, as this will display everything without stretching any pixels. So if a letter on the screen is six pixels tall, it will be displayed as exactly six pixels tall. But it will appear to be smaller this way, because there are almost twice as many pixels in the same size of screen.

'You know that's funny, but I have a friend who recently got back from X'
Now here's the important part. Did you friend enjoy their experience? Did they visit somewhere that was cool that they recommended? Did they run into any issues that your friend should know about?
'I heard that the snow there this time of year can be really bad!' I don't know why in the world your friend would be visiting Western New York, but so be it. Gives you a conversation while also showing that you have your concerns.
Or 'They went to this ramen place called Totto Ramen and said it was really good, you should try it out.' This actually did happen to me, this exact thing with one of my other friends, and you know what? It added to my trip to Manhattan.
Even things such as 'yeah, my friend stayed at this hotel and had a few things nearby worth checking out' gives people ideas for things to do while there. I mean at the end of the day, so long as you are adding to the conversation and presenting new ideas, you should be okay.

>>28103610
If you go into the military, they can't make you a motivated person. All they can do is tell you what the objective is, then you either do it or drop out. If you are not a motivated person already, you are not likely to survive boot camp.

You also have to take into consideration the physical and mental health requirements that you need to pass before you even get into boot camp. Are you well educated? Are you physically fit? Are you mentally sound? If the answer to any of these questions is "No", you might want to reconsider. A physical disability or a history of mental illness or a history of drug use can all disqualify you unless you get a waiver. The Marines are more strenuous than the Airforce, both physically and psycologically.

If you do successfully join, you cannot back out from the government contract that you sign. You will be given a "purpose", but I can almost guarantee you will not agree with it or like it. If doing what you are told without question is not your cup of tea, I would recommend a gym membership and a therapist instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I like how you posted probably one of the best shows that unironically may give you the answer to that
>dude it's TV with a bunch of scientologists, don't look into it that much
You should look up how Greg Garcia was going to end the series. In all seriousness though, if you have something you are passionate about or if you do something that makes you both feel good and improves you as a person, you're going to be a nicer person overall because you're not going to feel like absolute garbage when out with other people. One more thing- you don't magically become a good person just because you work out. From what you said in your post, it looks like you have other ways you have improved since you started working out, but other than that I can't really say, so here's some general tips.
>people like talking about themselves and their interests
It's a bit self-centered, but it is true. Give people the opportunity to talk about their day, their interests, their work, etc. Take genuine interest in it. Other people will also eventually let you talk about what you'd like.
>if you don't have anything nice to say, do not say anything
You should have heard this one as a kid. Obviously, use your best judgement on this one. You can call someone out if they are clearly doing something that impacts you or the wellbeing of others, but the idea is that the less intrusive you are, the more likable you are. If you want to suggest something, you should ask the person first if they would be free for critique if they do not know. People struggle with this one a lot these days, it's like people forgot how to actually communicate with each other.
>do things for your friends and make time for them
Never say, 'sorry, I don't have the time'. You can say what it is you have to do, but always give people a shot if they ask for it. Even little actions like picking someone up from the airport, being around for them if a family member dies, etc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28103780
2/probably 2
If you want to do something that feels good, consider the following:
>volunteer your time for charity work
Admittedly it is a bit cucked to work without pay, plus many communities are beyond saving. You can find interesting ways to make this happen however. Merely donating money is a hollow action. My cousins will often times travel to different countries with their churches to build houses for people that lost theirs due to natural disasters, for example.
>challenge yourself with learning something new
This is my go-to for general 'good feels'. My most recent thing is Isshin-ryu karate. Part of the problem with something new is that is that you will be bad at it, you may be unequipped for it, or you may end up not liking it after you invested a fair amount of money. That's not a bad thing either and this shouldn't stop you if you are interested in something initially.
>achieve at work
This is another thing that seems cucked, but can actually be really good. No matter who you are, all humans have a chemical that rewards them with good feelings for striving for something and completing it. Some people think that this is only dopamine, but there is another one that specifically gets rewarded to you for accomplishing goals- serotonin. In reality, dopamine is relatively short lived and has a higher high, but serotonin is what is essentially a mood stabilizer. I mention it here because serotonin, since it is rewarded through accomplishing hard work, is worthwhile to go for due to how many benefits you get. Plus side is that you can then use said accomplishments to put on a LinkedIn profile or resume (since companies don't promote anymore and you have to get promotions by job hopping).
Anyways, I hope my posts help. Stay off of the booze, stop thinking that improvement is a 2-dimensional return-reward system, consider some of my points and you will do fine.

>Should I go forward with my life and have a hard time finding a husband or sacrifice my hobbies, interests and ranch searching for a husband in the city?
Follow your dream. Especially for a sperg, you will be miserable if you end up in some shitty townhouse playing house with a guy you settled for. The easier thing is generally finding a guy who already wants--and preferably has--the kind of life you want, and you can move in with him (after getting married, of course). Off the top of my head, I would assume that groups or classes for DIY projects and skills (like woodworking) would have more guys interested in that kind of lifestyle. So you could try meeting people that way. You'd be preparing for your dream life either way, but you'd be more likely to find someone to share it with in the meantime.

>>28102905
>I'll also be miserable if I stay a single childless virgin
Those are all redundant. Changing any one of them without changing the others isn't going to make you happy in the long run, either.

This aside, you have a question of priorities: you want a husband and family, and you want to live in the countryside. If you don't want to sacrifice one or the other, then it makes sense to do what gives you the best chance of finding both. Finding a worthwhile life partner is hard, but the process doesn't depend on location. Living in the countryside, though, is something that you can obviously never do in the city.
This is why I suggest *preparing* for moving to your own dream place by attending classes, events, and so on. You will be giving yourself chances to meet someone special while also making definite progress towards at least one of your goals. If you just drop your plans and try to find any guy in the city, you might increase your dating pool (although the quality of most of the guys is questionable), but this chance comes with a higher risk that you'll never get to your preferred setting.

>Is he going to sell his house to find another one with me?
Homeownership rates aren't very high if you're in your 20s, so odds are he'd be more likely to move to a place you choose together once he marries you.

Also, this goes without saying, but don't get desperate for a partner. That opens you up to being taken advantage of.

>How do I accomplish this?
In order to do this you will have to actively resist what society values. This means constantly putting effort in to acting in this way. It will be like refusing to buy something when you are being forced to watch advertisements nonstop. It will require the development of virtues in order to guard against vice. There are some groups of people who can help you achieve this such as the religious, psychologists, or therapists, but at the end of the day, YOU will have to do the work and put in the effort to actively resist the influence of the world. There is no easy path to get there.

You may wish to minimize the influence of society in your daily life by simplifying and reducing the bounds of your "world" to make it more manageable. For example, being nice to your family, but not necessarily going out of your way to meet and help strangers. So you would be content to only being kind to those you really care about and interact with daily. If you are kind to everyone, you will be "punished" by society for your kindness.

>>28103151
You don't need an education degree to teach. I have an MA and have taught at a private school. It's quite common.

OP, there are lesson plans you can find online and plenty of of power points. I did take some education courses, and here's the heart of it: lecture and then assign. If you struggle with them paying attention, tell them the slides/board notes will be on the test. That will make them take notes. If they think you are bullshitting, le them fail that test. If it is a writing class, make sure they turn something in by the end. I have heard of teachers requiring students turn in slips that explains what they learned in that class. They can only leave when they turn it in. For math and stuff, if possible, through up an online quiz on what you discussed. It doesn't have to be graded, but make sure they do it.

Expected learning results is usually a charter school thing. Make a syllabus. Look at each thing you assign. What is something they should take away from each class? Write a sentence by each class on what is something they could learn for that day. Combine those sentences into a paragraph.

posts.sub: How do I get my parents to help my depressed NEET brother?
posts.com:
I don't understand why they let him rot the way they do.

This idea that people have where they watch someone making decisions that are ruining them, and think "well fuck, I dunno, that's what he wants to do", is so off to me. Clearly people dont want to end up worse off than they are, so why do we assume they want to do those things rather than considering the idea that they dont know any other way to do things?

Everything I'm talking about ultimately falls under the umbrella of common logic. Logic so simple that people dont see due to the complexity of their own bullshit.

If you prick someone with a pin, and they dont show pain, did you hurt them? Logic dictates, of course you did, you pricked them with a fucking pin. Theyre reaction and how you perceive it is inconsequential. Similar to seeing a fat fuck walking down the street eating pizza, you may think "well, that's what he wants to do is eat junk". Of course he doesnt want to eat junk, hes a fat fuck. There is no way he wants to be a fat fuck so why assume he wants to eat junk? Nobody ever thinks "maybe he doesnt know how not to do it, and is suffering in doing so". Replace with pizza and fat fuck with drugs/addict, etc, and it applies across the board.

I have had suicidal friends. I make the leap into their head the second they mention suicide. I understood that ANYTHING I think it feel doesnt matter. It's not my head where the problem lies, it's in theirs. Therefore I abide by the rules of their mind in order to fix this problem, because I care enough to see the problem as something that MUST be solved, I've reached the point that if it's someone who I DON'T care about, I don't even bother trying to help them. It'll be half-hearted and disingenuous, which always makes the person opening up to you feel worse once they realize it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28102935

I would room with a friend who is reliable and can pay bills. I'd also make step to have a reliable income. Living with a roommate at your income should be doable. The dog isn't idle but you can swing it. An expensive vet bill will be an issue sadly. Ultimately, you need to get out an environment that doesn't allow you to mature as an adult.

Keep in mind, shit sucks starting out with nothing. Make a budget and stick with it. Think about where you want to be in 10 years and make steps to get there. That could be college, getting certs, applying to certain jobs, etc. Keep an emergency fund and make sure money doesn't stress you out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Build credit, however that's done in your country.

Talk to your friends more seriously about moving out together, you need a hard yes with full commitment not a maybe before you start working towards something. If your friends are luke warm on the idea, then you're going to need to source a roommate elsewhere. Either way you'll need to set a hard date on when you will start looking at properties together.

The dog is going to make things very difficult. In the current rental crisis the dog is going to be the difference between finding a place and not. Leave the dog.

Look for a better job. Your current one doesn't earn enough. Aim to save $15K by the time you move.

Start looking at the rental market in your area to get an idea for what lessors are looking for from you and how much you're going to need to spend. If that full amount is more than 50% of either of your wages, you're going to have more trouble getting a place.

Start buying small bits and pieces for when you move out, so you don't have to spend it all as a lump sum. Sheets, towels, cutlery, cookware, plates, toilet brush, small appliances that kind of shit.
